<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Capital of Maharashtra, India</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Bombay" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Bombay_(disambiguation)" title="Bombay (disambiguation)">Bombay (disambiguation)</a> and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Mumbai_(disambiguation)" title="Mumbai (disambiguation)">Mumbai (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Mumbai</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><small>English: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="/ʊ/: 'u' in 'push'">ʊ</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/aɪ/: 'i' in 'tide'">aɪ</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mumbai_Pronunciation.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5f/Mumbai_Pronunciation.ogg" title="Mumbai Pronunciation.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>, <small>Marathi: </small><span class="IPA" lang="mr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Marathi" title="Help:IPA/Marathi">[ˈmumbəi]</a></span>; also known as <b>Bombay</b> <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/ɒ/: 'o' in 'body'">ɒ</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span></span>/</a></span></span>— <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_renamed_Indian_cities_and_states#Maharashtra" title="List of renamed Indian cities and states">the official name until 1995</a>) is the <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital city</a> of the Indian <a href="/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India" title="States and union territories of India">state</a> of <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> financial centre of <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, as of 2018, Mumbai is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_India_by_population" title="List of cities in India by population">second-most populous</a> city in India after <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities" title="List of largest cities">eighth-most populous</a> city in the world with a population of roughly 2 <a href="/wiki/Crore" title="Crore">crore</a> (20 million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNcities2018_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNcities2018-18">[18]</a></sup> As per the Indian government population census of 2011, Mumbai was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_India_by_population" title="List of cities in India by population">most populous city</a> in India with an estimated <a href="/wiki/City_proper" title="City proper">city proper</a> population of 1.25 crore (12.5 million) living under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Municipal_Corporation_of_Greater_Mumbai" title="Municipal Corporation of Greater Mumbai">Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cities1Lakhandabove_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cities1Lakhandabove-19">[19]</a></sup> Mumbai is the centre of the <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Metropolitan_Region" title="Mumbai Metropolitan Region">Mumbai Metropolitan Region</a>, the sixth most populous metropolitan area in the world with a population of over 2.3 crore (23 million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> Mumbai lies on the <a href="/wiki/Konkan" title="Konkan">Konkan</a> coast on the west coast of India and has a deep <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_harbour" title="Natural harbour">natural harbour</a>. In 2008, Mumbai was named an <a href="/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network" title="Globalization and World Cities Research Network">alpha world city</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lboro2008_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-lboro2008-21">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> It has the highest number of <a href="/wiki/Millionaire" title="Millionaire">millionaires</a> and <a href="/wiki/Billionaire" title="Billionaire">billionaires</a> among all cities in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>The seven islands that constitute Mumbai were earlier home to communities of <a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi language</a> speaking <a href="/wiki/Koli_people" title="Koli people">Koli people</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-james_customs_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-james_customs-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-munshi_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-munshi-26">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rnmehta_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-rnmehta-27">[27]</a></sup> For centuries, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seven_islands_of_Bombay" title="Seven islands of Bombay">seven islands of Bombay</a> were under the control of successive <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mumbai_under_indigenous_empires" title="History of Mumbai under indigenous empires">indigenous rulers</a> before being <a href="/wiki/Cession" title="Cession">ceded</a> to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire_in_the_East" title="Portuguese Empire in the East">Portuguese Empire</a>, and subsequently to the <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> in 1661, through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dowry_of_Catherine_Braganza" title="Dowry of Catherine Braganza">dowry of Catherine Braganza</a> when she was married off to <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II of England</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> During the mid-18th century, Bombay was reshaped by the <a href="/wiki/Hornby_Vellard" title="Hornby Vellard">Hornby Vellard</a> project,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dwivedi_2001_28_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dwivedi_2001_28-29">[29]</a></sup> which undertook reclamation of the area between the seven islands from the sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fp-onceuponatime_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-fp-onceuponatime-30">[30]</a></sup> Along with construction of major <a href="/wiki/Roads_in_India" title="Roads in India">roads</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_India" title="Rail transport in India">railways</a>, the reclamation project, completed in 1845, transformed Bombay into a major seaport on the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a>. Bombay in the 19th century was characterised by economic and educational development. During the early 20th century it became a strong base for the <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian independence movement</a>. Upon India's independence in 1947 the city was incorporated into <a href="/wiki/Bombay_State" title="Bombay State">Bombay State</a>. In 1960, following the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samyukta_Maharashtra_Movement" title="Samyukta Maharashtra Movement">Samyukta Maharashtra Movement</a>, a new state of Maharashtra was created with Bombay as the capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mumbai is the <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial</a>, commercial,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-millionaireRoleModel_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-millionaireRoleModel-32">[32]</a></sup> and the entertainment capital of India. It is also one of the world's top ten centres of commerce in terms of global financial flow,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> generating 6.16% of India's GDP,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mmrda_muip_gdp_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-mmrda_muip_gdp-34">[34]</a></sup> and accounting for 25% of industrial output, 70% of maritime trade in India (<a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Port_Trust" title="Mumbai Port Trust">Mumbai Port Trust</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_Port" title="Jawaharlal Nehru Port">JNPT</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> and 70% of capital transactions to <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_India" title="Economy of India">India's economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NMIAtender_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-NMIAtender-36">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> Mumbai has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_number_of_billionaires" title="List of cities by number of billionaires">eighth-highest number of billionaires</a> of any city in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> and Mumbai's billionaires had the highest average wealth of any city in the world in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> The city houses important financial institutions and the corporate <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_companies_headquartered_in_Mumbai" title="List of Indian companies headquartered in Mumbai">headquarters</a> of numerous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_companies" title="List of Indian companies">Indian companies</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multinational_corporations" title="Multinational corporations">multinational corporations</a>. It is also home to some of India's premier scientific and nuclear institutes. The city is also home to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Bollywood</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marathi_cinema" title="Marathi cinema">Marathi cinema</a> industries. Mumbai's business opportunities attract migrants from all over India.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
