<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The name <i>Mumbai</i> (<a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a>: <span title="Marathi-language text"><span lang="mr">मुंबई</span></span>, <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>: મુંબઈ, <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>: मुंबई) derived from <i>Mumbā</i> or <i>Mahā-Ambā</i>—the name of the patron goddess (<a href="/wiki/Kuladevata" title="Kuladevata">kuladevata</a>) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mumbadevi" title="Mumbadevi">Mumbadevi</a> of the native <a href="/wiki/Koli_people" title="Koli people">Koli</a> community<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>—and <i>ā'ī</i> meaning "mother" in the <a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi language</a>, which is the mother tongue of the Koli people and the official language of Maharashtra.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-james_customs_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-james_customs-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> The Koli people originated in <a href="/wiki/Kathiawar" title="Kathiawar">Kathiawar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Gujarat" title="Central Gujarat">Central Gujarat</a>, and according to some sources they brought their goddess Mumba with them from Kathiawar (Gujarat), where she is still worshipped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-munshi_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-munshi-26">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rnmehta_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-rnmehta-27">[27]</a></sup> However, other sources disagree that Mumbai's name was derived from the goddess Mumba.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rnmehta_27-2"><a href="#cite_note-rnmehta-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mumbadevi_temple.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="533" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Mumbadevi_temple.jpg/170px-Mumbadevi_temple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Mumbadevi_temple.jpg/255px-Mumbadevi_temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Mumbadevi_temple.jpg/340px-Mumbadevi_temple.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mumbadevi_temple.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Mumba_Devi_Temple" title="Mumba Devi Temple">Mumba Devi Temple</a>, from whom the city of Mumbai may derive its name</div></div></div>
<p>The oldest known names for the city are <i>Kakamuchee</i> and <i>Galajunkja</i>; these are sometimes still used.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> In 1508, Portuguese writer <a href="/wiki/Gaspar_Correia" title="Gaspar Correia">Gaspar Correia</a> used the name "Bombaim" in his <i>Lendas da Índia</i> (<i>Legends of India</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-et6yh_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-et6yh-46">[46]</a></sup> This name possibly originated as the <a href="/wiki/Galician-Portuguese" title="Galician-Portuguese">Galician-Portuguese</a> phrase <i>bom baim</i>, meaning "good little bay",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shirodkar_1998_7_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-Shirodkar_1998_7-47">[47]</a></sup> and <i>Bombaim</i> is still commonly used in Portuguese.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ety_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-ety-48">[48]</a></sup> In 1516, Portuguese explorer <a href="/wiki/Duarte_Barbosa" title="Duarte Barbosa">Duarte Barbosa</a> used the name <i>Tana-Maiambu</i>: <i>Tana</i> appears to refer to the adjoining town of <a href="/wiki/Thane" title="Thane">Thane</a> and <i>Maiambu</i> to <i>Mumbadevi</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other variations recorded in the 16th and the 17th centuries include: <i>Mombayn</i> (1525), <i>Bombay</i> (1538), <i>Bombain</i> (1552), <i>Bombaym</i> (1552), <i>Monbaym</i> (1554), <i>Mombaim</i> (1563), <i>Mombaym</i> (1644), <i>Bambaye</i> (1666), <i>Bombaiim</i> (1666), <i>Bombeye</i> (1676), <i>Boon Bay</i> (1690),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ety_48-1"><a href="#cite_note-ety-48">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etyh_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-etyh-50">[50]</a></sup> and <i>Bon Bahia</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/English_overseas_possessions" title="English overseas possessions">English</a> gained possession of the city in the 17th century, the Portuguese name was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglicise" title="Anglicise">anglicised</a> as <i>Bombay</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Ali Muhammad Khan, imperial <a href="/wiki/Dewan" title="Dewan">dewan</a> or revenue minister of the Gujarat province, in the <i>Mirat-i Ahmedi</i> (1762) referred to the city as <i>Manbai</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>The French traveller <a href="/wiki/Louis_Rousselet" title="Louis Rousselet">Louis Rousselet</a>, who visited in 1863 and 1868, states in his book <i>L’Inde des Rajahs</i>, which was first published in 1877: "Etymologists have wrongly derived this name from the Portuguese Bôa Bahia, or (French: "bonne bai", English: "good bay"), not knowing that the tutelar goddess of this island has been, from remote antiquity, Bomba, or <a href="/wiki/Mumba_Devi_Temple" title="Mumba Devi Temple">Mumba Devi</a>, and that she still ... possesses a temple".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the late 20th century, the city was referred to as <i>Mumbai</i> or <i>Mambai</i> in Marathi, <a href="/wiki/Konkani_language" title="Konkani language">Konkani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kannada_language" title="Kannada language">Kannada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">Sindhi</a>, and as <i>Bambai</i> in <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christopher_Beam_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher_Beam-55">[55]</a></sup> The Government of India officially changed the English name to <i>Mumbai</i> in November 1995.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> This came at the insistence of the Marathi nationalist <a href="/wiki/Shiv_Sena" title="Shiv Sena">Shiv Sena</a> party, which had just won the Maharashtra state elections, and mirrored <a href="/wiki/Renaming_of_cities_in_India" title="Renaming of cities in India">similar name changes across the country</a> and particularly in Maharashtra.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> According to <i><a href="/wiki/Slate_(magazine)" title="Slate (magazine)">Slate</a></i> magazine, "they argued that 'Bombay' was a corrupted English version of 'Mumbai' and an unwanted legacy of British colonial rule."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> <i>Slate</i> also said "The push to rename Bombay was part of a larger movement to strengthen Marathi identity in the Maharashtra region."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> While the city is still referred to as Bombay by some of its residents and by some Indians from other regions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24change_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-24change-60">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mummaharashtra1_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-mummaharashtra1-61">[61]</a></sup> mention of the city by a name other than <i>Mumbai</i> has been controversial, resulting in emotional outbursts, sometimes of a violently political nature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="People_from_Mumbai">People from Mumbai</span></h3>
<p>A resident of Mumbai is called <i>Mumbaikar</i> in <a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a>, in which the suffix <i>-kar</i> means a <i>resident of</i>. The term had been in use for quite some time but it gained popularity after the official name change to Mumbai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mumbaikar_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mumbaikar-64">[64]</a></sup> Older terms such as <i>Bombayite</i> are also in use.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mumbai" title="History of Mumbai">History of Mumbai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Mumbai" title="Timeline of Mumbai">Timeline of Mumbai</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mumbai_03-2016_94_Kanheri_Caves.jpg"><img alt="A white Buddhist stupa." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4051" data-file-width="2532" decoding="async" height="272" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Mumbai_03-2016_94_Kanheri_Caves.jpg/170px-Mumbai_03-2016_94_Kanheri_Caves.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Mumbai_03-2016_94_Kanheri_Caves.jpg/255px-Mumbai_03-2016_94_Kanheri_Caves.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Mumbai_03-2016_94_Kanheri_Caves.jpg/340px-Mumbai_03-2016_94_Kanheri_Caves.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mumbai_03-2016_94_Kanheri_Caves.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kanheri_Caves" title="Kanheri Caves">Kanheri Caves</a> contain Buddhist sculptures and paintings dating from the 1st century CE to the 10th century CE.</div></div></div>
<p>Mumbai is built on what was once an archipelago of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seven_islands_of_Bombay" title="Seven islands of Bombay">seven islands</a>: <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Bombay" title="Isle of Bombay">Isle of Bombay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parel" title="Parel">Parel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mazagaon" title="Mazagaon">Mazagaon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahim" title="Mahim">Mahim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colaba" title="Colaba">Colaba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Worli" title="Worli">Worli</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Old_Woman%27s_Island" title="Old Woman's Island">Old Woman's Island</a> (also known as <i>Little Colaba</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> It is not exactly known when these islands were first inhabited. <a href="/wiki/Pleistocene" title="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a> sediments found along the coastal areas around <a href="/wiki/Kandivali" title="Kandivali">Kandivali</a> in northern Mumbai suggest that the islands were inhabited since the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Stone_Age" title="South Asian Stone Age">South Asian Stone Age</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> Perhaps at the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">Common Era</a>, or possibly earlier, they came to be occupied by the Koli fishing community.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-city-profile_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-city-profile-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 3rd century BCE, the islands formed part of the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a>, during its expansion in the south, ruled by the Buddhist emperor <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a> of <a href="/wiki/Magadha" title="Magadha">Magadha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kanheri_Caves" title="Kanheri Caves">Kanheri Caves</a> in <a href="/wiki/Borivali" title="Borivali">Borivali</a> were excavated from basalt rock in the first century CE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ray_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ray-72">[72]</a></sup> and served as an important centre of Buddhism in Western India during ancient Times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> The city then was known as <i>Heptanesia</i> (<a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a>: A Cluster of Seven Islands) to the Greek geographer <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a> in 150 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mahakali_Caves" title="Mahakali Caves">Mahakali Caves</a> in <a href="/wiki/Andheri" title="Andheri">Andheri</a> were cut out between the 1st century BCE and the 6th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-battleneglect_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-battleneglect-75">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-threattocaves_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-threattocaves-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between the 2nd century BCE and 9th century CE, the islands came under the control of successive <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mumbai_under_indigenous_empires" title="History of Mumbai under indigenous empires">indigenous dynasties</a>: <a href="/wiki/Satavahana_dynasty" title="Satavahana dynasty">Satavahanas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Satraps" title="Western Satraps">Western Satraps</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abhira_Kingdom" title="Abhira Kingdom">Abhira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vakataka_dynasty" title="Vakataka dynasty">Vakataka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kalachuri_dynasty" title="Kalachuri dynasty">Kalachuris</a>, Konkan Mauryas, <a href="/wiki/Chalukya_dynasty" title="Chalukya dynasty">Chalukyas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rashtrakuta_dynasty" title="Rashtrakuta dynasty">Rashtrakutas</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> before being ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Shilahara" title="Shilahara">Shilaharas</a> from 810 to 1260.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> Some of the oldest edifices in the city built during this period are the <a href="/wiki/Jogeshwari_Caves" title="Jogeshwari Caves">Jogeshwari Caves</a> (between 520 and 525),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Elephanta_Caves" title="Elephanta Caves">Elephanta Caves</a> (between the sixth to seventh century),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Walkeshwar_Temple" title="Walkeshwar Temple">Walkeshwar Temple</a> (10th century),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Walkeshwar_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Walkeshwar-82">[82]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Banganga_Tank" title="Banganga Tank">Banganga Tank</a> (12th century).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Banganga_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-Banganga-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hajiali.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Hajiali.jpg/220px-Hajiali.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Hajiali.jpg/330px-Hajiali.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Hajiali.jpg/440px-Hajiali.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hajiali.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Haji_Ali_Dargah" title="Haji Ali Dargah">Haji Ali Dargah</a> was built in 1431, when Mumbai was under the rule of the <a href="/wiki/Gujarat_Sultanate" title="Gujarat Sultanate">Gujarat Sultanate</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Bhima_of_Mahikavati" title="Bhima of Mahikavati">King Bhimdev</a> founded his kingdom in the region in the late 13th century and established his capital in <i>Mahikawati</i> (present day <a href="/wiki/Mahim" title="Mahim">Mahim</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pathare_Prabhu" title="Pathare Prabhu">Pathare Prabhus</a>, among the earliest known settlers of the city, were brought to <i>Mahikawati</i> from <a href="/wiki/Saurashtra_(region)" title="Saurashtra (region)">Saurashtra</a> in Gujarat around 1298 by Bhimdev.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prabhu_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-prabhu-86">[86]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> annexed the islands in 1347–48 and controlled it until 1407. During this time, the islands were administered by the Muslim Governors of <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>, who were appointed by the Delhi Sultanate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>The islands were later governed by the independent <a href="/wiki/Gujarat_Sultanate" title="Gujarat Sultanate">Gujarat Sultanate</a>, which was established in 1407. The Sultanate's patronage led to the construction of many mosques, prominent being the <a href="/wiki/Haji_Ali_Dargah" title="Haji Ali Dargah">Haji Ali Dargah</a> in <a href="/wiki/Worli" title="Worli">Worli</a>, built in honour of the Muslim saint Haji Ali in 1431.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> From 1429 to 1431, the islands were a source of contention between the Gujarat Sultanate and the <a href="/wiki/Bahmani_Sultanate" title="Bahmani Sultanate">Bahmani Sultanate</a> of Deccan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mis_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-mis-91">[91]</a></sup> In 1493, <a href="/wiki/Bahadur_Khan_Gilani" title="Bahadur Khan Gilani">Bahadur Khan Gilani</a> of the Bahmani Sultanate attempted to conquer the islands but was defeated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Portuguese_and_British_rule">Portuguese and British rule</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bombay_under_Portuguese_rule_(1534%E2%80%931661)" title="History of Bombay under Portuguese rule (1534–1661)">History of Bombay under Portuguese rule (1534–1661)</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Bombay_under_British_rule" title="History of Bombay under British rule">History of Bombay under British rule</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Madh-fort3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="452" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Madh-fort3.jpg/220px-Madh-fort3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Madh-fort3.jpg/330px-Madh-fort3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Madh-fort3.jpg/440px-Madh-fort3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Madh-fort3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madh_Fort" title="Madh Fort">Madh Fort</a> built by the Portuguese, was one of the most important forts in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salsette" title="Salsette">Salsette</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, founded in 1526, was the dominant power in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> during the mid-16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> Growing apprehensive of the power of the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Humayun" title="Humayun">Humayun</a>, Sultan <a href="/wiki/Bahadur_Shah_of_Gujarat" title="Bahadur Shah of Gujarat">Bahadur Shah of Gujarat</a> was obliged to sign the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Bassein_(1534)" title="Treaty of Bassein (1534)">Treaty of Bassein</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a> on 23 December 1534. According to the treaty, the Seven Islands of Bombay, the nearby strategic town of <a href="/wiki/Vasai" title="Vasai">Bassein</a> and its dependencies were offered to the Portuguese. The territories were later surrendered on 25 October 1535.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Portuguese were actively involved in the foundation and growth of their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> religious orders in Bombay.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> They called the islands by various names, which finally took the written form <i>Bombaim</i>. The islands were leased to several Portuguese officers during their regime. The Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Franciscans" title="Franciscans">Franciscans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jesuits" title="Jesuits">Jesuits</a> built several churches in the city, prominent being the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Church_(Mumbai)" title="St. Michael's Church (Mumbai)">St. Michael's Church</a> at <a href="/wiki/Mahim" title="Mahim">Mahim</a> (1534),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/St._John_the_Baptist_Church,_Mumbai" title="St. John the Baptist Church, Mumbai">St. John the Baptist Church</a> at <a href="/wiki/Andheri" title="Andheri">Andheri</a> (1579),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Andrew%27s_Church_(Mumbai)" title="St. Andrew's Church (Mumbai)">St. Andrew's Church</a> at <a href="/wiki/Bandra" title="Bandra">Bandra</a> (1580),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Church" title="Gloria Church">Gloria Church</a> at <a href="/wiki/Byculla" title="Byculla">Byculla</a> (1632).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gc_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-gc-99">[99]</a></sup> The Portuguese also built several fortifications around the city like the <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Castle" title="Bombay Castle">Bombay Castle</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Castella_de_Aguada" title="Castella de Aguada">Castella de Aguada</a></i> (Castelo da Aguada or Bandra Fort), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madh_Fort" title="Madh Fort">Madh Fort</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_Empire" title="English Empire">English</a> were in constant struggle with the Portuguese vying for hegemony over Bombay, as they recognised its strategic natural harbour and its natural isolation from land attacks. By the middle of the 17th century the growing power of the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Empire" title="Dutch Empire">Dutch Empire</a> forced the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_Empire" title="English Empire">English</a> to acquire a station in western India. On 11 May 1661, the marriage treaty of <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II of England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catherine_of_Braganza" title="Catherine of Braganza">Catherine of Braganza</a>, daughter of <a href="/wiki/John_IV_of_Portugal" title="John IV of Portugal">King John IV of Portugal</a>, placed the islands in possession of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_Empire" title="English Empire">English Empire</a>, as part of Catherine's <a href="/wiki/Dowry" title="Dowry">dowry</a> to Charles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/Salsette_Island" title="Salsette Island">Salsette</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasai" title="Vasai">Bassein</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mazagaon" title="Mazagaon">Mazagaon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parel" title="Parel">Parel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Worli" title="Worli">Worli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sion,_Mumbai" title="Sion, Mumbai">Sion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dharavi" title="Dharavi">Dharavi</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wadala_Road" title="Wadala Road">Wadala</a> still remained under Portuguese possession. From 1665 to 1666, the English managed to acquire Mahim, Sion, Dharavi, and Wadala.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AMH-6748-NA_Two_views_of_the_English_fort_in_Bombay.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2145" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/AMH-6748-NA_Two_views_of_the_English_fort_in_Bombay.jpg/220px-AMH-6748-NA_Two_views_of_the_English_fort_in_Bombay.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/AMH-6748-NA_Two_views_of_the_English_fort_in_Bombay.jpg/330px-AMH-6748-NA_Two_views_of_the_English_fort_in_Bombay.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/AMH-6748-NA_Two_views_of_the_English_fort_in_Bombay.jpg/440px-AMH-6748-NA_Two_views_of_the_English_fort_in_Bombay.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AMH-6748-NA_Two_views_of_the_English_fort_in_Bombay.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Two views of the English fort in Bombay, c. 1665</div></div></div>
<p>In accordance with the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Charter_of_27_March_1668" title="Royal Charter of 27 March 1668">Royal Charter of 27 March 1668</a>, England leased these islands to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_East_India_Company" title="English East India Company">English East India Company</a> in 1668 for a sum of <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">£</a>10 per annum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> The population quickly rose from 10,000 in 1661, to 60,000 in 1675.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> The islands were subsequently attacked by <a href="/wiki/Yakut_Khan" title="Yakut Khan">Yakut Khan</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> <a href="/wiki/Koli_people" title="Koli people">Koli</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> admiral of the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, in October 1672,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-y72_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-y72-108">[108]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rickloffe_van_Goen" title="Rickloffe van Goen">Rickloffe van Goen</a>, the Governor-General of <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch India</a> on 20 February 1673,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Siddi" title="Siddi">Siddi</a> admiral <a href="/wiki/Siddi_Sambal" title="Siddi Sambal">Sambal</a> on 10 October 1673.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-y72_108-1"><a href="#cite_note-y72-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1687, the English East India Company transferred its headquarters from <a href="/wiki/Surat" title="Surat">Surat</a> to Bombay. The city eventually became the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Presidency" title="Bombay Presidency">Bombay Presidency</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> Following the transfer, Bombay was placed at the head of all the company's establishments in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> Towards the end of the 17th century, the islands again suffered incursions from Yakut Khan in 1689–90.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iexpress_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-iexpress-112">[112]</a></sup> The Portuguese presence ended in Bombay when the <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Marathas</a> under <i><a href="/wiki/Peshwa" title="Peshwa">Peshwa</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Baji_Rao_I" title="Baji Rao I">Baji Rao I</a> captured <a href="/wiki/Salsette_Island" title="Salsette Island">Salsette</a> in 1737, and <a href="/wiki/Vasai" title="Vasai">Bassein</a> in 1739.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
By the middle of the 18th century, Bombay began to grow into a major trading town, and received a huge influx of migrants from across India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Later, the British occupied Salsette on 28 December 1774. With the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Surat" title="Treaty of Surat">Treaty of Surat</a> (1775), the British formally gained control of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salsette" title="Salsette">Salsette</a> and Bassein, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/First_Anglo-Maratha_War" title="First Anglo-Maratha War">First Anglo-Maratha War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> The British were able to secure Salsette from the Marathas without violence through the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Purandar_(1776)" title="Treaty of Purandar (1776)">Treaty of Purandar (1776)</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> and later through the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Salbai" title="Treaty of Salbai">Treaty of Salbai</a> (1782), signed to settle the outcome of the First Anglo-Maratha War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour,_1731.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="610" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour%2C_1731.jpg/220px-Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour%2C_1731.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour%2C_1731.jpg/330px-Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour%2C_1731.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour%2C_1731.jpg/440px-Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour%2C_1731.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour,_1731.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ships in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bombay_Harbour" title="Bombay Harbour">Bombay Harbour</a> (c. 1731). Bombay emerged as a significant trading town during the mid-18th century.</div></div></div>
<p>From 1782 onwards, the city was reshaped with large-scale civil engineering projects aimed at merging all the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seven_islands_of_Bombay" title="Seven islands of Bombay">seven islands of Bombay</a> into a single amalgamated mass by way of a <a href="/wiki/Causeway" title="Causeway">causeway</a> called the <a href="/wiki/Hornby_Vellard" title="Hornby Vellard">Hornby Vellard</a>, which was completed by 1784.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dwivedi_2001_28_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dwivedi_2001_28-29">[29]</a></sup> In 1817, the British East India Company under <a href="/wiki/Mountstuart_Elphinstone" title="Mountstuart Elphinstone">Mountstuart Elphinstone</a> defeated <a href="/wiki/Baji_Rao_II" title="Baji Rao II">Baji Rao II</a>, the last of the Maratha <i>Peshwa</i> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Khadki" title="Battle of Khadki">Battle of Khadki</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> Following his defeat, almost the whole of the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan Plateau</a> came under British suzerainty, and was incorporated into the Bombay Presidency. The success of the British campaign in the Deccan marked the end of all attacks by native powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 1845, the seven islands coalesced into a single landmass by the Hornby Vellard project via large scale <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">land reclamation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fp-onceuponatime_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-fp-onceuponatime-30">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mumfact_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-mumfact-120">[120]</a></sup> On 16 April 1853, India's first passenger railway line was established, connecting Bombay to the neighbouring town of <a href="/wiki/Thane" title="Thane">Thana</a> (now Thane).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> (1861–1865), the city became the world's chief cotton-trading market, resulting in a boom in the economy that subsequently enhanced the city's stature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>The opening of the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a> in 1869 transformed Bombay into one of the largest seaports on the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> In September 1896, Bombay was hit by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mumbai_plague_epidemic" title="Mumbai plague epidemic">bubonic plague epidemic</a> where the death toll was estimated at 1,900 people per week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> About 850,000 people fled Bombay and the textile industry was adversely affected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> While the city was the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Presidency" title="Bombay Presidency">Bombay Presidency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian independence movement</a> fostered the <a href="/wiki/Quit_India_Movement" title="Quit India Movement">Quit India Movement</a> in 1942 and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Indian_Navy_mutiny" title="Royal Indian Navy mutiny">Royal Indian Navy mutiny</a> in 1946.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independent_India">Independent India</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Bombay_in_Independent_India" title="History of Bombay in Independent India">History of Bombay in Independent India</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Victoria_Terminus,_Bombay_in_1950.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="638" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Victoria_Terminus%2C_Bombay_in_1950.jpg/220px-Victoria_Terminus%2C_Bombay_in_1950.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Victoria_Terminus%2C_Bombay_in_1950.jpg/330px-Victoria_Terminus%2C_Bombay_in_1950.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Victoria_Terminus%2C_Bombay_in_1950.jpg/440px-Victoria_Terminus%2C_Bombay_in_1950.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Victoria_Terminus,_Bombay_in_1950.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Municipal_Corporation_Building,_Mumbai" title="Municipal Corporation Building, Mumbai">Municipal Corporation Building, Bombay</a> in 1950 (Victoria Terminus partly visible on far right)</div></div></div>
<p>After India's independence in 1947, the territory of the <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Presidency" title="Bombay Presidency">Bombay Presidency</a> retained by India was restructured into <a href="/wiki/Bombay_State" title="Bombay State">Bombay State</a>. The area of Bombay State increased, after several erstwhile princely states that joined the Indian union were integrated into the state. Subsequently, the city became the capital of Bombay State.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> In April 1950, Municipal limits of Bombay were expanded by merging the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mumbai_suburban_district" title="Mumbai suburban district">Bombay Suburban District</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mumbai_city_district" title="Mumbai city district">Bombay City</a> to form the Greater Bombay Municipal Corporation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samyukta_Maharashtra_movement" title="Samyukta Maharashtra movement">Samyukta Maharashtra movement</a> to create a separate Maharashtra state including Bombay was at its height in the 1950s. In the <i><a href="/wiki/Lok_Sabha" title="Lok Sabha">Lok Sabha</a></i> discussions in 1955, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Congress party</a> demanded that the city be constituted as an autonomous city-state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/States_Reorganisation_Act" title="States Reorganisation Act">States Reorganisation</a> Committee recommended a bilingual state for Maharashtra–<a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a> with Bombay as its capital in its 1955 report. <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Citizens%27_Committee" title="Bombay Citizens' Committee">Bombay Citizens' Committee</a>, an advocacy group of leading <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_people" title="Gujarati people">Gujarati</a> industrialists lobbied for Bombay's independent status.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>
Following protests during the movement in which 105 people lost their lives in clashes with the police, Bombay State was reorganised on linguistic lines on 1 May 1960.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>-speaking areas of Bombay State were partitioned into the state of Gujarat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> Maharashtra State with Bombay as its capital was formed with the merger of <a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a>-speaking areas of Bombay State, eight districts from <a href="/wiki/Central_Provinces_and_Berar" title="Central Provinces and Berar">Central Provinces and Berar</a>, five districts from <a href="/wiki/Hyderabad_State" title="Hyderabad State">Hyderabad State</a>, and numerous princely states enclosed between them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> As a memorial to the martyrs of the Samyukta Maharashtra movement, Flora Fountain was renamed as <i><a href="/wiki/Hutatma_Chowk" title="Hutatma Chowk">Hutatma Chowk</a></i> (Martyr's Square) and a memorial was erected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> </p><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hutatma_Chowk.jpg"><img alt="A stone statue of torch-bearers as seen at night. A fountain with a white base is in the background" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="763" data-file-width="451" decoding="async" height="288" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Hutatma_Chowk.jpg/170px-Hutatma_Chowk.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Hutatma_Chowk.jpg/255px-Hutatma_Chowk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Hutatma_Chowk.jpg/340px-Hutatma_Chowk.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hutatma_Chowk.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Hutatma_Chowk" title="Hutatma Chowk">Hutatma Chowk</a> memorial, built to honour the martyrs of the <a href="/wiki/Samyukta_Maharashtra_Samiti" title="Samyukta Maharashtra Samiti">Samyukta Maharashtra movement</a> (<a href="/wiki/Flora_Fountain" title="Flora Fountain">Flora Fountain</a> on its left in the background)</div></div></div><p>The following decades saw massive expansion of the city and its suburbs. In the late 1960s, <a href="/wiki/Nariman_Point" title="Nariman Point">Nariman Point</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cuffe_Parade" title="Cuffe Parade">Cuffe Parade</a> were reclaimed and developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Metropolitan_Region_Development_Authority" title="Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority">Bombay Metropolitan Region Development Authority</a> (BMRDA) was established on 26 January 1975 by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Maharashtra" title="Government of Maharashtra">Government of Maharashtra</a> as an apex body for planning and co-ordination of development activities in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mumbai_metropolitan_area" title="Mumbai metropolitan area">Bombay metropolitan region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> In August 1979, a sister township of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Bombay" title="New Bombay">New Bombay</a> was founded by the <a href="/wiki/City_and_Industrial_Development_Corporation" title="City and Industrial Development Corporation">City and Industrial Development Corporation</a> (CIDCO) across the <a href="/wiki/Thane_district" title="Thane district">Thane</a> and <a href="/wiki/Raigad_district" title="Raigad district">Raigad districts</a> to help the dispersal and control of Bombay's population. The textile industry in Bombay largely disappeared after the widespread 1982 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Bombay_Textile_Strike" title="Great Bombay Textile Strike">Great Bombay Textile Strike</a>, in which nearly 250,000 workers in more than 50 textile mills went on strike.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-a_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-a-138">[138]</a></sup> Mumbai's defunct cotton mills have since become the focus of <a href="/wiki/Redevelopment_of_Mumbai_mills" title="Redevelopment of Mumbai mills">intense redevelopment</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-skylimit_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-skylimit-139">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-revisitmills_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-revisitmills-140">[140]</a></sup> Industrial development began in Mumbai. When its economy started focusing on the fields of petrochemicals, electronics, electronics and automobile. In 1954 <a href="/wiki/Hindustan_Petroleum" title="Hindustan Petroleum">Hindustan Petroleum</a> comissoned <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Refinery_(HPCL)" title="Mumbai Refinery (HPCL)">Mumbai Refinery</a> at <a href="/wiki/Trombay" title="Trombay">Trombay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Refinery_(BPCL)" title="Mumbai Refinery (BPCL)">BPCL Refinery</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_Port" title="Jawaharlal Nehru Port">Jawaharlal Nehru Port</a>, which handles 55–60% of India's containerized cargo, was commissioned on 26 May 1989 across the creek at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nhava_Sheva" title="Nhava Sheva">Nhava Sheva</a> with a view to de-congest <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Harbour" title="Mumbai Harbour">Bombay Harbour</a> and to serve as a hub port for the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> The geographical limits of Greater Bombay were coextensive with municipal limits of Greater Bombay. On 1 October 1990, the Greater Bombay district was bifurcated to form two revenue districts namely, <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_City_district" title="Mumbai City district">Bombay City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Suburban_district" title="Mumbai Suburban district">Bombay Suburban</a>, though they continued to be administered by same Municipal Administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>The years from 1990 to 2010 saw an increase in violence and terrorism activities. Following the <a href="/wiki/Demolition_of_the_Babri_Masjid" title="Demolition of the Babri Masjid">demolition of the Babri Masjid</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ayodhya" title="Ayodhya">Ayodhya</a>, the city was rocked by the <a href="/wiki/Bombay_riots" title="Bombay riots">Hindu-Muslim riots of 1992–93</a> in which more than 1,000 people were killed. In March 1993, <a href="/wiki/1993_Bombay_bombings" title="1993 Bombay bombings">a series of 13 coordinated bombings</a> at several city landmarks by <a href="/wiki/Islamic_extremism" title="Islamic extremism">Islamic extremists</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mumbai_underworld#Mumbai_underworld" title="Mumbai underworld">Bombay underworld</a> resulted in 257 deaths and over 700 injuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> In 2006, 209 people were killed and over 700 injured when <a href="/wiki/2006_Mumbai_train_bombings" title="2006 Mumbai train bombings">seven bombs exploded</a> on the city's <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Suburban_Railway" title="Mumbai Suburban Railway">commuter trains</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> In 2008, a series of <a href="/wiki/2008_Mumbai_attacks" title="2008 Mumbai attacks">ten coordinated attacks</a> by armed terrorists for three days resulted in 173 deaths, 308 injuries, and severe damage to several heritage landmarks and prestigious hotels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Casualties_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-Casualties-146">[146]</a></sup> The three coordinated <a href="/wiki/2011_Mumbai_bombings" title="2011 Mumbai bombings">bomb explosions in July 2011</a> that occurred at the <a href="/wiki/Opera_house" title="Opera house">Opera house</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zaveri_Bazaar" title="Zaveri Bazaar">Zaveri Bazaar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dadar" title="Dadar">Dadar</a> were the latest in the series of terrorist attacks in Mumbai which resulted in 26 deaths and 130 injuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13_July_Mumbai_bombings_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-13_July_Mumbai_bombings-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mumbai is the commercial capital of India and has evolved into a global financial hub.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mumbai_global_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mumbai_global-149">[149]</a></sup> For several decades it has been the home of India's main financial services, and a focus for both infrastructure development and private investment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> From being an ancient fishing community and a colonial centre of trade, Mumbai has become South Asia's largest city and home of the world's most prolific film industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Mumbai" title="Geography of Mumbai">Geography of Mumbai</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/South_Mumbai" title="South Mumbai">South Mumbai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Suburbs_(Mumbai)" title="Western Suburbs (Mumbai)">Western Suburbs (Mumbai)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Suburbs_(Mumbai)" title="Eastern Suburbs (Mumbai)">Eastern Suburbs (Mumbai)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_neighbourhoods_in_Mumbai" title="List of neighbourhoods in Mumbai">List of neighbourhoods in Mumbai</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mumbaicitydistricts.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="339" data-file-width="200" decoding="async" height="288" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Mumbaicitydistricts.png/170px-Mumbaicitydistricts.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/Mumbaicitydistricts.png 1.5x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mumbaicitydistricts.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mumbai consists of two revenue districts.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Urban-Rural_Population_and_Land_Area_Estimates,_v2,_2010_Mumbai,_India_(13874140314).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2417" data-file-width="3178" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Urban-Rural_Population_and_Land_Area_Estimates%2C_v2%2C_2010_Mumbai%2C_India_%2813874140314%29.jpg/220px-Urban-Rural_Population_and_Land_Area_Estimates%2C_v2%2C_2010_Mumbai%2C_India_%2813874140314%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Urban-Rural_Population_and_Land_Area_Estimates%2C_v2%2C_2010_Mumbai%2C_India_%2813874140314%29.jpg/330px-Urban-Rural_Population_and_Land_Area_Estimates%2C_v2%2C_2010_Mumbai%2C_India_%2813874140314%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Urban-Rural_Population_and_Land_Area_Estimates%2C_v2%2C_2010_Mumbai%2C_India_%2813874140314%29.jpg/440px-Urban-Rural_Population_and_Land_Area_Estimates%2C_v2%2C_2010_Mumbai%2C_India_%2813874140314%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Urban-Rural_Population_and_Land_Area_Estimates,_v2,_2010_Mumbai,_India_(13874140314).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population density and elevation above sea level in Mumbai, India (2010). Mumbai is especially vulnerable to <a href="/wiki/Sea_level_rise" title="Sea level rise">sea level rise</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Mumbai is on a narrow peninsula on the southwest of <a href="/wiki/Salsette_Island" title="Salsette Island">Salsette Island</a>, which lies between the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> to the west, <a href="/wiki/Thane_Creek" title="Thane Creek">Thane Creek</a> to the east and <a href="/wiki/Vasai_Creek" title="Vasai Creek">Vasai Creek</a> to the north. Mumbai's suburban district occupies most of the island. <a href="/wiki/Navi_Mumbai" title="Navi Mumbai">Navi Mumbai</a> is east of Thane Creek and <a href="/wiki/Thane" title="Thane">Thane</a> is north of <a href="/wiki/Vasai_Creek" title="Vasai Creek">Vasai Creek</a>. Mumbai consists of two distinct regions: <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_City_district" title="Mumbai City district">Mumbai City district</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Suburban_district" title="Mumbai Suburban district">Mumbai Suburban district</a>, which form two separate revenue districts of Maharashtra.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> The city district region is also commonly referred to as the <i>Island City</i> or <a href="/wiki/South_Mumbai" title="South Mumbai">South Mumbai</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mmrda_muip_gdp_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-mmrda_muip_gdp-34">[34]</a></sup> The total area of Mumbai is 603.4 km<sup>2</sup> (233 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> Of this, the island city spans 67.79 km<sup>2</sup> (26 sq mi), while the suburban district spans 370 km<sup>2</sup> (143 sq mi), together accounting for 437.71 km<sup>2</sup> (169 sq mi) under the administration of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Municipal_Corporation_of_Greater_Mumbai" title="Municipal Corporation of Greater Mumbai">Municipal Corporation of Greater Mumbai</a> (MCGM). The remaining areas belong to various Defence establishments, the <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Port_Trust" title="Mumbai Port Trust">Mumbai Port Trust</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Atomic_Energy_Commission_of_India" title="Atomic Energy Commission of India">Atomic Energy Commission</a> and the Borivali National Park, which are out of the jurisdiction of the MCGM.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trf_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-trf-154">[154]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Metropolitan_Region" title="Mumbai Metropolitan Region">Mumbai Metropolitan Region</a> which includes portions of <a href="/wiki/Thane_district" title="Thane district">Thane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palghar_district" title="Palghar district">Palghar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Raigad_district" title="Raigad district">Raigad</a> districts in addition to Greater Mumbai, covers an area of 4,355 km<sup>2</sup> (1681.5 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-projectsecoa1_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-projectsecoa1-6">[6]</a></sup>
Mumbai lies at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Ulhas_River" title="Ulhas River">Ulhas River</a> on the western coast of India, in the coastal region known as the <a href="/wiki/Konkan" title="Konkan">Konkan</a>. It sits on <a href="/wiki/Salsette_Island" title="Salsette Island">Salsette Island</a> (Sashti Island), which it partially shares with the <a href="/wiki/Thane_district" title="Thane district">Thane district</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-geo_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-geo-155">[155]</a></sup> Mumbai is bounded by the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> to the west.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mloc_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-mloc-156">[156]</a></sup> Many parts of the city lie just above sea level, with elevations ranging from 10 m (33 ft) to 15 m (49 ft);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> the city has an average elevation of 14 m (46 ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wbase_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wbase-158">[158]</a></sup> Northern Mumbai (Salsette) is hilly,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> and the highest point in the city is 450 m (1,476 ft) at Salsette in the <a href="/wiki/Powai" title="Powai">Powai</a>–<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kanheri" title="Kanheri">Kanheri</a> ranges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sanjay_Gandhi_National_Park" title="Sanjay Gandhi National Park">Sanjay Gandhi National Park</a> (Borivali National Park) is located partly in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mumbai_suburban_district" title="Mumbai suburban district">Mumbai suburban district</a>, and partly in the Thane district, and it extends over an area of 103.09 km<sup>2</sup> (39.80 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>Apart from the <a href="/wiki/Bhatsa_Dam" title="Bhatsa Dam">Bhatsa Dam</a>, there are six major lakes that supply water to the city: <a href="/wiki/Vihar_Lake" title="Vihar Lake">Vihar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_Vaitarna_Dam" title="Middle Vaitarna Dam">Lower Vaitarna</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upper_Vaitarna_Dam" title="Upper Vaitarna Dam">Upper Vaitarna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tulsi_Lake" title="Tulsi Lake">Tulsi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tansa_Dam" title="Tansa Dam">Tansa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Powai" title="Powai">Powai</a>. Tulsi Lake and Vihar Lake are located in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Borivili_National_Park" title="Borivili National Park">Borivili National Park</a>, within the city's limits. The supply from Powai lake, also within the city limits, is used only for agricultural and industrial purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> Three small rivers, the <a href="/wiki/Dahisar_River" title="Dahisar River">Dahisar River</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poisar_River" title="Poisar River">Poinsar (or Poisar)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oshiwara_River" title="Oshiwara River">Ohiwara (or Oshiwara)</a> originate within the park, while the polluted <a href="/wiki/Mithi_River" title="Mithi River">Mithi River</a> originates from Tulsi Lake and gathers water overflowing from Vihar and Powai Lakes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> The coastline of the city is indented with numerous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Creek_(tidal)" title="Creek (tidal)">creeks</a> and bays, stretching from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thane_creek" title="Thane creek">Thane creek</a> on the
eastern to Madh Marve on the western front.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> The eastern coast of Salsette Island is covered with large <a href="/wiki/Mangrove" title="Mangrove">mangrove</a> <a href="/wiki/Swamp" title="Swamp">swamps</a>, rich in biodiversity, while the western coast is mostly sandy and rocky.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>Soil cover in the city region is predominantly sandy due to its proximity to the sea. In the suburbs, the soil cover is largely alluvial and loamy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> The underlying rock of the region is composed of black <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan</a> basalt flows, and their acidic and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basic_(chemistry)" title="Basic (chemistry)">basic</a> variants dating back to the late <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a> and early <a href="/wiki/Eocene" title="Eocene">Eocene</a> eras.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> Mumbai sits on a <a href="/wiki/Seismicity" title="Seismicity">seismically active</a> zone owing to the presence of 23 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fault_line" title="Fault line">fault lines</a> in the vicinity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> The area is classified as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Earthquake_hazard_zoning_of_India" title="Earthquake hazard zoning of India">Seismic Zone III region</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> which means an earthquake of up to magnitude 6.5 on the Richter magnitude scale may be expected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Mumbai" title="Climate of Mumbai">Climate of Mumbai</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Climate_Action_Plan" title="Mumbai Climate Action Plan">Mumbai Climate Action Plan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:India_mumbai_temperature_precipitation_averages_chart.svg"><img alt="The average temperature ranges between 23 °C (73 °F) in January to 30 °C (86 °F) in May. Rainfall is at or near zero from November through May, then quickly rises to a peak of about 600 mm (23.62 in) in July, falling back more gradually." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="562" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/India_mumbai_temperature_precipitation_averages_chart.svg/220px-India_mumbai_temperature_precipitation_averages_chart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/India_mumbai_temperature_precipitation_averages_chart.svg/330px-India_mumbai_temperature_precipitation_averages_chart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/India_mumbai_temperature_precipitation_averages_chart.svg/440px-India_mumbai_temperature_precipitation_averages_chart.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:India_mumbai_temperature_precipitation_averages_chart.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Average temperature and precipitation in Mumbai</div></div></div>
<p>Mumbai has a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical climate</a>, specifically a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_savanna_climate" title="Tropical savanna climate">tropical wet and dry climate</a> (Aw) under the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a>. It varies between a dry period extending from October to May and a wet period peaking in June.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> The cooler season from December to February is followed by the hotter season from March to May. The period from June to about the end of September constitutes the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monsoon_of_Indian_subcontinent" title="Monsoon of Indian subcontinent">south west monsoon</a> season, and October and November form the post-monsoon season.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between June and September, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South-west_monsoon" title="South-west monsoon">South-west monsoon</a> rains occur in Mumbai. Pre-monsoon showers are received in May. Occasionally, north-east monsoon showers occur in October and November. The maximum annual rainfall ever recorded was 3,452 mm (136 in) for 1954.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clra_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-clra-173">[173]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2005_Mumbai_floods" title="2005 Mumbai floods">highest rainfall</a> recorded in a single day was 944 mm (37 in) on <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra_floods_of_2005" title="Maharashtra floods of 2005">26 July 2005</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> The average total annual rainfall is 2,213.4 mm (87 in) for the Island City, and 2,502.3 mm (99 in) for the suburbs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clra_173-1"><a href="#cite_note-clra-173">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>The average annual temperature is 27 °C (81 °F), and the average annual <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">precipitation</a> is 2,213 mm (87 in).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> In the Island City, the average maximum temperature is 31 °C (88 °F), while the average minimum temperature is 24 °C (75 °F). In the suburbs, the daily mean maximum temperature range from 29 °C (84 °F) to 33 °C (91 °F), while the daily mean minimum temperature ranges from 16 °C (61 °F) to 26 °C (79 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clra_173-2"><a href="#cite_note-clra-173">[173]</a></sup> The record high is 42.2 °C (108 °F) set on 14 April 1952,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMDextremes_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-IMDextremes-176">[176]</a></sup> and the record low is 7.4 °C (45 °F) set on 27 January 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMDextremes_176-1"><a href="#cite_note-IMDextremes-176">[176]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p>Tropical Cyclones are rare in the city, The worst Cyclone to ever impact Mumbai was the 1948 Mumbai Cyclone where gusts reached 151 km/h (94 mph) in Juhu, The storm left 38 people dead and 47 missing, The storm reportedly impacted Bombay for 20 hours and left the city devastated <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mumbai is prone to <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> floods,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> caused due to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> that is affected by heavy rains and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_tide" title="High tide">high tide</a> in the sea, according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, unplanned drainage system and <a href="/wiki/Informal_housing" title="Informal housing">informal settlement</a> is a key factor of frequent floods in Mumbai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WEF_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-WEF-183">[183]</a></sup> Among other causes of flooding in Mumbai is its <a href="/wiki/Geographical_feature" title="Geographical feature">geographic location</a>, Mumbai urban is in peninsular form, (a land-filled area that connects seven islands) a low laying area, compared to its suburb that sits on an elevated location, Over the past few decades, the new informal settlements were formed in the suburb, causing a rapid increase in population, Improper waste management, and drainage congestion. The rainwater from these areas heavily flows towards low-lying urban areas consisting of substantial slums and high-rise buildings. As a result, poorly constructed slums are either <a href="/wiki/Swamp" title="Swamp">swamped</a>, washed away, or collapse causing heavy casualties, and post-flood water logging lasts for a long time that causing blockage of railway lines-(most frequently used public transport in Mumbai), traffic snarl, inundated roads, and sub-merged bylanes. Over the past few decades, the frequency of floods in Mumbai is enormous, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2005_Mumbai_floods" title="2005 Mumbai floods">2005 Mumbai floods</a> are characterized by 500-1000 deaths, household displacements, damaged infrastructure-(including heritage sites), and a financial loss of <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$</span> 1.2 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WEF_183-1"><a href="#cite_note-WEF-183">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-david,david&amp;Janel_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-david,david&amp;Janel-184">[184]</a></sup> In the process of reducing floods in Mumbai, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maharashtra_government" title="Maharashtra government">Maharashtra government</a> adopted a flood mitigation plan; according to which the drainage system will be restructured, restoration of <a href="/wiki/Mithi_River" title="Mithi River">Mithi River</a>, and re-establishment of informal settlements. Local civic body <a href="/wiki/Brihanmumbai_Municipal_Corporation" title="Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation">Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation</a> (BMC) authorities are assigned to forecast and issue eviction notices while BMC along with NGO's prepare for the evacuation of slum dwellers to temporary safe camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WEF_183-2"><a href="#cite_note-WEF-183">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-david,david&amp;Janel_184-1"><a href="#cite_note-david,david&amp;Janel-184">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LSC_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-LSC-185">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<div>

<tr style="text-align: center;">

<td style="background: #0E0EFF; color:#FFFFFF;">63

<td style="background: #3030FF; color:#FFFFFF;">54
