</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a></td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:blue; width:3.27%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">3.27%</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Others</td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:black; width:1.15%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.15%</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
</div>
</div>
<p>The religious groups represented in Mumbai as of 2011 include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindus</a> (65.99%), <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a> (20.65%), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist">Buddhists</a> (4.85%), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jain" title="Jain">Jains</a> (4.10%), <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> (3.27%) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">Sikhs</a> (0.49%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census2011_344-1"><a href="#cite_note-census2011-344">[344]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup> The linguistic/ethnic demographics in the Greater Mumbai Area are: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maharashtrians" title="Maharashtrians">Maharashtrians</a> (32%), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gujaratis" title="Gujaratis">Gujaratis</a> (20%), with the rest hailing from other parts of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup>
</p><p>Native Christians include <a href="/wiki/East_Indians" title="East Indians">East Indian Catholics</a>, who were converted by the Portuguese during the 16th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Goan_Catholics" title="Goan Catholics">Goan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mangalorean_Catholics" title="Mangalorean Catholics">Mangalorean Catholics</a> also constitute a significant portion of the Christian community of the city.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Mumbai" title="History of the Jews in Mumbai">Jews settled in Bombay</a> during the 18th century. The <a href="/wiki/Bene_Israel" title="Bene Israel">Bene Israeli</a> Jewish community of Bombay, who migrated from the <a href="/wiki/Konkan" title="Konkan">Konkan</a> villages, south of Bombay, are believed to be the descendants of the Jews of Israel who were shipwrecked off the Konkan coast, probably in the year 175 BCE, during the reign of the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a> ruler, <a href="/wiki/Antiochus_IV_Epiphanes" title="Antiochus IV Epiphanes">Antiochus IV Epiphanes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup> Mumbai is also home to the largest population of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">Parsi</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zoroastrian" title="Zoroastrian">Zoroastrians</a> in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[350]</a></sup> numbering about 60,000, however their population is declining rapidly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[351]</a></sup> Parsis migrated to India from <a href="/wiki/Greater_Iran" title="Greater Iran">Greater Iran</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Muslim conquest of Persia</a> in the seventh century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup> The oldest Muslim communities in Mumbai include the <a href="/wiki/Dawoodi_Bohra" title="Dawoodi Bohra">Dawoodi Bohras</a>, Ismaili <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khojas" title="Khojas">Khojas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Konkani_Muslims" title="Konkani Muslims">Konkani Muslims</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">
<div class="mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black;transform:scaleX(-1)rotate(-90deg)">
<div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:grey"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 222.96788315689px; border-left-color:gold"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:gold"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:gold"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 44.021887101067px; border-left-color:green"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:green"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:green"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:64.705596156944px 76.244251101145px 0 0; border-top-color:orange"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:orange"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 75.57454800484px 100px 0; border-right-color:red"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:red"></div>
</div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<p>Languages in Mumbai (2011)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census2011-langreport_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-census2011-langreport-354">[354]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:red; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a> (35.30%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:orange; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a> (25.90%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:green; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a> (20.40%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:gold; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> (11.69%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:grey; color:black;"> </span> Others (11.64%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a> is the official language and the working language in bureaucracy of the city along with <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindi_Language" title="Hindi Language">Hindi</a>. Mumbai has a large polyglot population like all other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Status_of_Indian_cities" title="Status of Indian cities">metropolitan cities</a> of India. Sixteen major <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_India" title="Languages of India">languages of India</a> are spoken in Mumbai, with the most common being <a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a> and its dialect <a href="/wiki/East_Indian_language" title="East Indian language">East Indian</a>. These are spoken by 4,396,870 people which is 32.24% of the population(Marathi as a single language is spoken by 22% of the population).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup> Hindi is spoken by 3,582,719 of the population that's 25.90% of the population making it the second largest dominat language in Mumbai. Many Hindi speakers are workers from Uttar Pradesh and Bihar who migrate seasonally to Mumbai to work as labourers. Gujarati with 2,640,990 speakers is spoken by 20.4% of the population, making it the third largest language after Marathi and Hindi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other languages spoken include <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> is spoken by 11.69% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[360]</a></sup> English is extensively spoken and is the principal language of the city's <a href="/wiki/White-collar_worker" title="White-collar worker">white collar</a> workforce. A colloquial form of Hindi, known as <i><a href="/wiki/Bombay_Hindi" title="Bombay Hindi">Bambaiya</a></i> – a blend of Hindi, Marathi, Gujarati, <a href="/wiki/Konkani_language" title="Konkani language">Konkani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indian_English" title="Indian English">Indian English</a> and some invented words – is spoken on the streets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[361]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kannada" title="Kannada">Kannada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Telugu_language" title="Telugu language">Telugu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malayalam" title="Malayalam">Malayalam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odia_language" title="Odia language">Odia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">Sindhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tulu_language" title="Tulu language">Tulu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Assamese_language" title="Assamese language">Assamese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhojpuri" title="Bhojpuri">Bhojpuri</a> are other minority languages spoken in Mumbai.
</p><p>In the Suburbs, Marathi is spoken by 36.78% of the population of suburban Mumbai, and <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a> by 31.21%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Food">Food</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Street_food_of_Mumbai" title="Street food of Mumbai">Street food of Mumbai</a></div>
<p>Mumbai has a variety of street food, including the <a href="/wiki/Vada_pav" title="Vada pav">Vada pav</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tt04_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-tt04-363">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dna11_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-dna11-364">[364]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_culture" title="Mumbai culture">Mumbai culture</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mumbai_03-2016_70_Asiatic_Society_Library.jpg"><img alt="A white building with a triangular façade and wide stairs" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3211" data-file-width="4817" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Mumbai_03-2016_70_Asiatic_Society_Library.jpg/220px-Mumbai_03-2016_70_Asiatic_Society_Library.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Mumbai_03-2016_70_Asiatic_Society_Library.jpg/330px-Mumbai_03-2016_70_Asiatic_Society_Library.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Mumbai_03-2016_70_Asiatic_Society_Library.jpg/440px-Mumbai_03-2016_70_Asiatic_Society_Library.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mumbai_03-2016_70_Asiatic_Society_Library.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Asiatic_Society_of_Mumbai" title="The Asiatic Society of Mumbai">The Asiatic Society of Mumbai</a> is one of the oldest <a href="/wiki/Public_library" title="Public library">public libraries</a> in the city.</div></div></div>
<p>Mumbai's culture offers a blend of traditional and cosmopolitan festivals, food, entertainment, and night life. The city's cosmopolitan and urban-centric modern cultural offerings are comparable to other world capitals. Mumbai bears the distinction of being the most cosmopolitan city of India. Its history as a major trading centre and the expansion of an education middle class has led to a diverse range of cultures, religions, and cuisines coexisting in the city. The variety and abundance of restaurants, cinemas, theatres, sports events and museums are a product of Mumbai's unique cosmopolitan culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[365]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mumbai is the birthplace of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_cinema" title="Indian cinema">Indian cinema</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[366]</a></sup>—<a href="/wiki/Dadasaheb_Phalke" title="Dadasaheb Phalke">Dadasaheb Phalke</a> laid the foundations with silent movies followed by <a href="/wiki/Marathi_cinema" title="Marathi cinema">Marathi talkies</a>—and the oldest film broadcast took place in the early 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[367]</a></sup> Mumbai also has a large number of cinema halls that feature Bollywood, Marathi and Hollywood movies. The <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_International_Film_Festival" title="Mumbai International Film Festival">Mumbai International Film Festival</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[368]</a></sup> and the award ceremony of the <a href="/wiki/Filmfare_Awards" title="Filmfare Awards">Filmfare Awards</a>, the oldest and prominent film awards given for Hindi film industry in India, are held in Mumbai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[369]</a></sup> Despite most of the professional theatre groups that formed during the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a> having disbanded by the 1950s, Mumbai has developed a thriving "theatre movement" tradition in Marathi, Hindi, English, and other regional languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-multitheater_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-multitheater-370">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[371]</a></sup>
</p><p>Contemporary art is featured in both government-funded art spaces and private commercial galleries. The government-funded institutions include the <a href="/wiki/Jehangir_Art_Gallery" title="Jehangir Art Gallery">Jehangir Art Gallery</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Modern_Art" title="National Gallery of Modern Art">National Gallery of Modern Art</a>. Built in 1833, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asiatic_Society_of_Bombay" title="Asiatic Society of Bombay">Asiatic Society of Bombay</a> is one of the oldest <a href="/wiki/Public_library" title="Public library">public libraries</a> in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[372]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chhatrapati_Shivaji_Maharaj_Vastu_Sangrahalaya" title="Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya">Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya</a> (formerly The Prince of Wales Museum) is a renowned museum in <a href="/wiki/South_Mumbai" title="South Mumbai">South Mumbai</a> which houses rare ancient exhibits of Indian history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[373]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mumbai has a zoo named <a href="/wiki/Jijamata_Udyaan" title="Jijamata Udyaan">Jijamata Udyaan</a> (formerly Victoria Gardens), which also harbor's a garden. The rich literary traditions of the city have been highlighted internationally by <a href="/wiki/Booker_Prize" title="Booker Prize">Booker Prize</a> winners <a href="/wiki/Salman_Rushdie" title="Salman Rushdie">Salman Rushdie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aravind_Adiga" title="Aravind Adiga">Aravind Adiga</a>. <a href="/wiki/Marathi_literature" title="Marathi literature">Marathi literature</a> has been modernized in the works of Mumbai-based authors such as Mohan Apte, <a href="/wiki/Anant_Kanekar" title="Anant Kanekar">Anant Kanekar</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gangadhar_Gadgil" title="Gangadhar Gadgil">Gangadhar Gadgil</a>, and is promoted through an annual <a href="/wiki/Sahitya_Akademi_Award" title="Sahitya Akademi Award">Sahitya Akademi Award</a>, a literary honor bestowed by India's <a href="/wiki/Sahitya_Akademi" title="Sahitya Akademi">National Academy of Letters</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[374]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chowpatti_Beach_(Girgaum_Chowpatty).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Chowpatti_Beach_%28Girgaum_Chowpatty%29.jpg/220px-Chowpatti_Beach_%28Girgaum_Chowpatty%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Chowpatti_Beach_%28Girgaum_Chowpatty%29.jpg/330px-Chowpatti_Beach_%28Girgaum_Chowpatty%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Chowpatti_Beach_%28Girgaum_Chowpatty%29.jpg/440px-Chowpatti_Beach_%28Girgaum_Chowpatty%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chowpatti_Beach_(Girgaum_Chowpatty).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Girgaum_Chowpatty" title="Girgaum Chowpatty">Girgaum Chowpatty</a> beach. Beaches are a popular tourist attraction in the city.</div></div></div>
<p>Mumbai residents celebrate both Western and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_festivals" title="Indian festivals">Indian festivals</a>. <a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holi" title="Holi">Holi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eid_ul-Fitr" title="Eid ul-Fitr">Eid</a>, Christmas, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Navratri" title="Navratri">Navratri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Good_Friday" title="Good Friday">Good Friday</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Navrati" title="Navrati">Dussera</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moharram" title="Moharram">Moharram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ganesh_Chaturthi" title="Ganesh Chaturthi">Ganesh Chaturthi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Durga_Puja" title="Durga Puja">Durga Puja</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maha_Shivratri" title="Maha Shivratri">Maha Shivratri</a> are some of the popular festivals in the city. The <a href="/wiki/Kala_Ghoda_Arts_Festival" title="Kala Ghoda Arts Festival">Kala Ghoda Arts Festival</a> is an exhibition of a world of arts that encapsulates works of artists in the fields of music, dance, theatre, and films.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup> A week-long annual fair known as <a href="/wiki/Bandra_Fair" title="Bandra Fair">Bandra Fair</a>, starting on the following Sunday after 8 September, is celebrated by people of all faiths, to commemorate the <a href="/wiki/Nativity_of_Mary" title="Nativity of Mary">Nativity of Mary</a>, mother of Jesus, on 8 September.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mid1_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-mid1-376">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Banganga Festival is a two-day music festival, held annually in the month of January, which is organised by the <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra_Tourism_Development_Corporation" title="Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation">Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation</a> (MTDC) at the historic <a href="/wiki/Banganga_Tank" title="Banganga Tank">Banganga Tank</a> in Mumbai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTDCpullout_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTDCpullout-377">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTDCBanganga_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTDCBanganga-378">[378]</a></sup> The Elephanta Festival—celebrated every February on the <a href="/wiki/Elephanta_Island" title="Elephanta Island">Elephanta Islands</a>—is dedicated to classical Indian dance and music and attracts performers from across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTDCpullout_377-1"><a href="#cite_note-MTDCpullout-377">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTDCElephanta_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTDCElephanta-379">[379]</a></sup> Public holidays specific to the city and the state include <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra_Day" title="Maharashtra Day">Maharashtra Day</a> on 1 May, to celebrate the formation of Maharashtra state on 1 May 1960,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Gudi_Padwa" title="Gudi Padwa">Gudi Padwa</a> which is the New Year's Day for <a href="/wiki/Marathi_people" title="Marathi people">Marathi people</a>.
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Mumbai_beaches" title="List of Mumbai beaches">Beaches</a> are a major tourist attraction in the city. The major beaches in Mumbai are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Girgaum_Chowpatty" title="Girgaum Chowpatty">Girgaum Chowpatty</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Juhu_Beach" title="Juhu Beach">Juhu Beach</a>, Dadar Chowpatty, Gorai Beach, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marve_Beach" title="Marve Beach">Marve Beach</a>, Versova Beach, Madh Beach, <a href="/wiki/Aksa_Beach" title="Aksa Beach">Aksa Beach</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Manori" title="Manori">Manori</a> Beach.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup> Most of the beaches are unfit for swimming, except Girgaum Chowpatty and Juhu Beach.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup> Essel World is a theme park and amusement centre situated close to Gorai Beach,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup> and includes Asia's largest theme water park, Water Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adlabs_Imagica" title="Adlabs Imagica">Adlabs Imagica</a> opened in April 2013 is located near the city of Khopoli off the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mumbai-Pune_Expressway" title="Mumbai-Pune Expressway">Mumbai-Pune Expressway</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-founderimagica_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-founderimagica-386">[386]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Mumbai_radio_stations" title="List of Mumbai radio stations">List of Mumbai radio stations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Times_of_India_Building.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Times_of_India_Building.jpg/220px-Times_of_India_Building.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Times_of_India_Building.jpg/330px-Times_of_India_Building.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Times_of_India_Building.jpg/440px-Times_of_India_Building.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Times_of_India_Building.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Times_of_India" title="The Times of India">The Times of India</a>'</i>s first office is opposite the <a href="/wiki/Chhatrapati_Shivaji_Terminus" title="Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus">Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus</a> where it was founded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-televisionpoint2006_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-televisionpoint2006-387">[387]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Mumbai has numerous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_newspapers" title="Indian newspapers">newspaper</a> publications, television and radio stations. Marathi dailies enjoy the maximum readership share in the city and the top <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marathi-language_newspapers" title="Marathi-language newspapers">Marathi language newspapers</a> are <i><a href="/wiki/Maharashtra_Times" title="Maharashtra Times">Maharashtra Times</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Nava_Kaal" title="Nava Kaal">Navakaal</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Lokmat" title="Lokmat">Lokmat</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Loksatta_(newspaper)" title="Loksatta (newspaper)">Loksatta</a></i>, <i>Mumbai Chaufer</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Saamana" title="Saamana">Saamana</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sakaal" title="Sakaal">Sakaal</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[388]</a></sup> Popular Marathi language magazines are <i>Saptahik Sakaal</i>, <i>Grihashobhika</i>, <i>Lokrajya</i>, <i>Lokprabha</i> &amp; <i>Chitralekha</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup> Popular English language newspapers published and sold in Mumbai include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times_of_India" title="The Times of India">The Times of India</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MiD_DAY" title="MiD DAY">Mid-day</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Hindustan_Times" title="Hindustan Times">Hindustan Times</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/DNA_India" title="DNA India">DNA India</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Indian_Express" title="The Indian Express">The Indian Express</a></i>. Newspapers are also printed in other Indian languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup> Mumbai is home to Asia's oldest newspaper, <i><a href="/wiki/Bombay_Samachar" title="Bombay Samachar">Bombay Samachar</a></i>, which has been published in Gujarati since 1822.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[391]</a></sup> <i>Bombay Durpan</i>, the first Marathi newspaper, was started by <a href="/wiki/Balshastri_Jambhekar" title="Balshastri Jambhekar">Balshastri Jambhekar</a> in Mumbai in 1832.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PubliclifeMSG_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-PubliclifeMSG-392">[392]</a></sup>
</p><p>Numerous <a href="/wiki/Television_in_India" title="Television in India">Indian</a> and international television channels can be watched in Mumbai through one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pay-tv" title="Pay-tv">Pay TV</a> companies or the local cable television provider. The metropolis is also the hub of many international media corporations, with many news channels and print publications having a major presence. The national television broadcaster, <a href="/wiki/Doordarshan" title="Doordarshan">Doordarshan</a>, provides two free terrestrial channels, while three main cable networks serve most households.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[393]</a></sup>
</p><p>The wide range of cable channels available includes <a href="/wiki/Zee_Marathi" title="Zee Marathi">Zee Marathi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zee_Talkies" title="Zee Talkies">Zee Talkies</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ETV_Marathi" title="ETV Marathi">ETV Marathi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Star_Pravah" title="Star Pravah">Star Pravah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mi_Marathi" title="Mi Marathi">Mi Marathi</a>, DD Sahyadri (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marathi_language_television" title="Marathi language television">All Marathi channels</a>), news channels such as <a href="/wiki/ABP_Majha" title="ABP Majha">ABP Majha</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IBN-Lokmat" title="IBN-Lokmat">IBN-Lokmat</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zee_24_Taas" title="Zee 24 Taas">Zee 24 Taas</a>, sports channels like <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a>, <a href="/wiki/Star_Sports_(Indian_TV_network)" title="Star Sports (Indian TV network)">Star Sports</a>, National entertainment channels like <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Colors_(TV_channel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Colors (TV channel) (page does not exist)">Colors</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sony_Entertainment_Television_(India)" title="Sony Entertainment Television (India)">Sony</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zee_TV" title="Zee TV">Zee TV</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Star_Plus" title="Star Plus">Star Plus</a>, business news channels like <a href="/wiki/CNBC_Awaaz" title="CNBC Awaaz">CNBC Awaaz</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zee_Business" title="Zee Business">Zee Business</a>, <a href="/wiki/ET_Now" title="ET Now">ET Now</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bloomberg_UTV" title="Bloomberg UTV">Bloomberg UTV</a>. News channels entirely dedicated to Mumbai include Sahara Samay Mumbai. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zing_(TV_channel)" title="Zing (TV channel)">Zing</a> a popular Bollywood gossip channel is also based out of Mumbai. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct_broadcast_satellite" title="Direct broadcast satellite">Satellite television</a> (DTH) has yet to gain mass acceptance, due to high installation costs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[394]</a></sup> Prominent DTH entertainment services in Mumbai include <a href="/wiki/Dish_TV" title="Dish TV">Dish TV</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tata_Sky" title="Tata Sky">Tata Sky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[395]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are twelve radio stations in Mumbai, with nine broadcasting on the <a href="/wiki/Frequency_modulation" title="Frequency modulation">FM</a> band, and three <a href="/wiki/All_India_Radio" title="All India Radio">All India Radio</a> stations broadcasting on the <a href="/wiki/Amplitude_modulation" title="Amplitude modulation">AM</a> band.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> Mumbai also has access to <a href="/wiki/Commercial_broadcasting" title="Commercial broadcasting">Commercial radio</a> providers such as <a href="/wiki/Sirius_Satellite_Radio" title="Sirius Satellite Radio">Sirius</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conditional_Access_System" title="Conditional Access System">Conditional Access System</a> (CAS) started by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Union Government</a> in 2006 met a poor response in Mumbai due to competition from its sister technology <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct_broadcast_satellite" title="Direct broadcast satellite">Direct-to-Home</a> (DTH) transmission service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Bollywood</a>, the Hindi film industry based in Mumbai, produces around 150–200 films every year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup> The name Bollywood is a blend of Bombay and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States" title="Cinema of the United States">Hollywood</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup> The 2000s saw a growth in Bollywood's popularity overseas. This led filmmaking to new heights in terms of quality, cinematography and innovative story lines as well as technical advances such as special effects and animation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[400]</a></sup> Studios in Goregaon, including <a href="/wiki/Film_City,_Mumbai" title="Film City, Mumbai">Film City</a>, are the location for most movie sets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup> The city also hosts the <a href="/wiki/Marathi_cinema" title="Marathi cinema">Marathi film industry</a> which has seen increased popularity in recent years, and TV production companies. Mumbai is a hub of Indian film making. Several other Indian language films such as <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhojpuri" title="Bhojpuri">Bhojpuri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malayalam" title="Malayalam">Malayalam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Telugu_language" title="Telugu language">Telugu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> are also occasionally shot in Mumbai. <a href="/wiki/Slumdog_Millionaire" title="Slumdog Millionaire">Slumdog Millionaire</a>, an <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English language</a> British film, was shot entirely in Mumbai and has garnered 8 Oscar awards.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_educational_institutions_in_Mumbai#Schools" title="List of educational institutions in Mumbai">List of educational institutions in Mumbai § Schools</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_colleges_in_Mumbai" title="List of colleges in Mumbai">List of colleges in Mumbai</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mumbai_03-2016_39_University.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5472" data-file-width="3420" decoding="async" height="272" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mumbai_03-2016_39_University.jpg/170px-Mumbai_03-2016_39_University.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mumbai_03-2016_39_University.jpg/255px-Mumbai_03-2016_39_University.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mumbai_03-2016_39_University.jpg/340px-Mumbai_03-2016_39_University.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mumbai_03-2016_39_University.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rajabai_Clock_Tower" title="Rajabai Clock Tower">Rajabai Clock Tower</a> at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Mumbai" title="University of Mumbai">University of Mumbai</a> is part of <a href="/wiki/The_Victorian_and_Art_Deco_Ensemble_of_Mumbai" title="The Victorian and Art Deco Ensemble of Mumbai">The Victorian and Art Deco Ensemble</a>, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Schools">Schools</span></h3>
<p>Schools in Mumbai are either "municipal schools" (run by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Municipal_Corporation_of_Greater_Mumbai" title="Municipal Corporation of Greater Mumbai">MCGM</a>) or private schools (run by trusts or individuals), which in some cases receive financial aid from the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup> The schools are affiliated with either of the following boards:
</p>
<ul><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maharashtra_State_Secondary_and_Higher_Secondary_Education_Board" title="Maharashtra State Secondary and Higher Secondary Education Board">Maharashtra State Board</a> (MSBSHSE)</li>
<li>The All-India <a href="/wiki/Council_for_the_Indian_School_Certificate_Examinations" title="Council for the Indian School Certificate Examinations">Council for the Indian School Certificate Examinations</a> (CISCE)</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Open_Schooling" title="National Institute of Open Schooling">National Institute of Open Schooling</a> (NIOS)</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Central_Board_of_Secondary_Education" title="Central Board of Secondary Education">Central Board for Secondary Education</a> (CBSE)</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/International_Baccalaureate" title="International Baccalaureate">International Baccalaureate</a> (IB)</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/International_General_Certificate_of_Secondary_Education" title="International General Certificate of Secondary Education">International General Certificate of Secondary Education</a> (IGCSE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup> Marathi or English is the usual language of instruction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>The primary education system of the MCGM is the largest urban primary education system in Asia. The MCGM operates 1,188 primary schools imparting primary education to 485,531 students in eight languages (<a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Telugu_language" title="Telugu language">Telugu</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kannada_language" title="Kannada language">Kannada</a>). The MCGM also imparts secondary education to 55,576 students through its 49 secondary schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Higher_education">Higher education</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:University_Mumbai_convoc_hall.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/University_Mumbai_convoc_hall.jpg/200px-University_Mumbai_convoc_hall.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/University_Mumbai_convoc_hall.jpg/300px-University_Mumbai_convoc_hall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/University_Mumbai_convoc_hall.jpg/400px-University_Mumbai_convoc_hall.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:University_Mumbai_convoc_hall.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/University_of_Mumbai" title="University of Mumbai">University of Mumbai</a> is one of the largest universities in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[406]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/10%2B2%2B3_plan" title="10+2+3 plan">10+2+3/4 plan</a>, students complete ten years of schooling and then enrol for two years in <a href="/wiki/Junior_college" title="Junior college">junior college</a>, where they select one of three streams: arts, commerce, or science.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[407]</a></sup> This is followed by either a general degree course in a chosen field of study, or a professional degree course, such as law, engineering and medicine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[408]</a></sup> Most colleges in the city are affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Mumbai" title="University of Mumbai">University of Mumbai</a>, one of the largest universities in the world in terms of the number of graduates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[409]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Mumbai" title="University of Mumbai">University of Mumbai</a> is one of the premier<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-intoday1_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-intoday1-410">[410]</a></sup> universities in India. It was ranked 41 among the Top 50 Engineering Schools of the world by America's news broadcasting firm <i><a href="/wiki/Business_Insider" title="Business Insider">Business Insider</a></i> in 2012 and was the only university in the list from the five emerging BRICS nations viz Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Business_Insider_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-Business_Insider-411">[411]</a></sup> Moreover, the University of Mumbai was ranked 5th in the list of best universities in India by <i><a href="/wiki/India_Today" title="India Today">India Today</a></i> in 2013<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup> and ranked at 62 in the QS BRICS University rankings for 2013, a ranking of leading universities in the five BRICS countries (Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-topuniversities.com_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-topuniversities.com-413">[413]</a></sup>
Its strongest scores in the QS University Rankings: BRICS are for papers per faculty (8th), employer reputation (20th) and citations per paper (28th).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-414">[414]</a></sup>
It was ranked 10th among the top Universities of India by QS in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_414-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-414">[414]</a></sup> With 7 of the top ten Indian Universities being purely science and technology universities, it was India's 3rd best <a href="/wiki/Interdisciplinarity" title="Interdisciplinarity">Multi Disciplinary</a> University in the QS University ranking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_414-2"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-414">[414]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IITBMainBuildingCROP.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/IITBMainBuildingCROP.jpg/220px-IITBMainBuildingCROP.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/IITBMainBuildingCROP.jpg/330px-IITBMainBuildingCROP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/IITBMainBuildingCROP.jpg/440px-IITBMainBuildingCROP.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IITBMainBuildingCROP.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Bombay" title="Indian Institute of Technology Bombay">Indian Institute of Technology Bombay</a> is a premier engineering institute in the country.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/IIT_Bombay" title="IIT Bombay">Indian Institute of Technology Bombay</a> (IIT Bombay), Mumbai,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Chemical_Technology" title="Institute of Chemical Technology">Institute of Chemical Technology</a> (formerly UDCT / UICT),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[416]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/VJTI" title="VJTI">Veermata Jijabai Technological Institute</a> (VJTI),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[417]</a></sup> which are India's premier engineering and technology schools, along with <a href="/wiki/SNDT_Women%27s_University" title="SNDT Women's University">SNDT Women's University</a> are the autonomous universities located in Mumbai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[418]</a></sup> In April 2015, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Bombay" title="Indian Institute of Technology Bombay">IIT Bombay</a> launched the first U.S.-India joint EMBA program alongside <a href="/wiki/Washington_University_in_St._Louis" title="Washington University in St. Louis">Washington University in St. Louis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Thadomal_Shahani_Engineering_College" title="Thadomal Shahani Engineering College">Thadomal Shahani Engineering College</a> is the first and the oldest private engineering college affiliated to the federal <a href="/wiki/University_of_Mumbai" title="University of Mumbai">University of Mumbai</a> and is also pioneered to be the first institute in the city's university to offer undergraduate level courses in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Computer_Engineering" title="Computer Engineering">Computer Engineering</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Information_Technology" title="Information Technology">Information Technology</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biomedical_Engineering" title="Biomedical Engineering">Biomedical Engineering</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">Biotechnology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grant_Medical_College" title="Grant Medical College">Grant Medical College</a> established in 1845 and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seth_G.S._Medical_College" title="Seth G.S. Medical College">Seth G.S. Medical College</a> are the leading medical institutes affiliated with <a href="/wiki/Grant_Medical_College_and_Sir_Jamshedjee_Jeejeebhoy_Group_of_Hospitals" title="Grant Medical College and Sir Jamshedjee Jeejeebhoy Group of Hospitals">Sir Jamshedjee Jeejeebhoy Group of Hospitals</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/KEM_Hospital" title="KEM Hospital">KEM Hospital</a> respectively. Mumbai is also home to <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Industrial_Engineering" title="National Institute of Industrial Engineering">National Institute of Industrial Engineering</a> (NITIE), <a href="/wiki/Jamnalal_Bajaj_Institute_of_Management_Studies" title="Jamnalal Bajaj Institute of Management Studies">Jamnalal Bajaj Institute of Management Studies</a> (JBIMS), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Narsee_Monjee_Institute_of_Management_Studies" title="Narsee Monjee Institute of Management Studies">Narsee Monjee Institute of Management Studies</a> (NMIMS), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S_P_Jain_Institute_of_Management_and_Research" title="S P Jain Institute of Management and Research">S P Jain Institute of Management and Research</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Social_Sciences" title="Tata Institute of Social Sciences">Tata Institute of Social Sciences</a> (TISS) and several other management schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Government_Law_College,_Mumbai" title="Government Law College, Mumbai">Government Law College</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sydenham_College" title="Sydenham College">Sydenham College</a>, respectively the oldest law and commerce colleges in India, are based in Mumbai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sir_J._J._School_of_Art" title="Sir J. J. School of Art">Sir J. J. School of Art</a> is Mumbai's oldest art institution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup>
It also has one of the best law schools or universities of the country which is <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra_National_Law_University,_Mumbai" title="Maharashtra National Law University, Mumbai">National Law Universities</a> (NLU).
</p><p>Mumbai is home to two prominent research institutions: the <a href="/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Fundamental_Research" title="Tata Institute of Fundamental Research">Tata Institute of Fundamental Research</a> (TIFR), and the <a href="/wiki/Bhabha_Atomic_Research_Centre" title="Bhabha Atomic Research Centre">Bhabha Atomic Research Centre</a> (BARC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup> The BARC operates <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIRUS" title="CIRUS">CIRUS</a>, a 40 MW nuclear research reactor at their facility in <a href="/wiki/Trombay" title="Trombay">Trombay</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup>
</p><p><b>Bombay Veterinary College</b> now Mumbai Veterinary College is the oldest and premier Veterinary College of India and Asia. Its foundation stone is laid in the year of 1886.
</p><p>The <b>ICAR-Central Institute of Fisheries Education</b> (<b>CIFE</b>) is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deemed_to_be_University" title="Deemed to be University">Deemed to be University</a> and institution of higher learning for <a href="/wiki/Fisheries_science" title="Fisheries science">fisheries science</a> in Mumbai, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. CIFE has over four decades of leadership in human resource development with its alumni aiding in the development of fisheries and <a href="/wiki/Aquaculture" title="Aquaculture">aquaculture</a> worldwide, producing notable contributions to research and technological advancements to its credit. The institute is one of four deemed to be universities operating under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Council_for_Agricultural_Research" title="Indian Council for Agricultural Research">Indian Council for Agricultural Research</a> (ICAR); the other three being the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Veterinary_Research_Institute" title="Indian Veterinary Research Institute">Indian Veterinary Research Institute</a> (IVRI), the [National Dairy Research Institute] (NDRI) and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Agriculture_Research_Institute" title="Indian Agriculture Research Institute">Indian Agriculture Research Institute</a> (IARI)
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wankhede_ICC_WCF.jpg"><img alt="A grassy ground with skyscrapers behind it" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Wankhede_ICC_WCF.jpg/220px-Wankhede_ICC_WCF.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Wankhede_ICC_WCF.jpg/330px-Wankhede_ICC_WCF.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Wankhede_ICC_WCF.jpg/440px-Wankhede_ICC_WCF.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">33,000<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup> people can be accommodated in the <a href="/wiki/Wankhede_Stadium" title="Wankhede Stadium">Wankhede Stadium</a>.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bombay18.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1152" data-file-width="1728" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Bombay18.jpg/220px-Bombay18.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Bombay18.jpg/330px-Bombay18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Bombay18.jpg/440px-Bombay18.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Built in 1883, <a href="/wiki/Mahalaxmi_Racecourse" title="Mahalaxmi Racecourse">Mahalaxmi Racecourse</a> was created out of a marshy land known as Mahalakshmi Flats.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">Cricket</a> is more popular than any other sport in the city. Mumbai is home to the <a href="/wiki/Board_of_Control_for_Cricket_in_India" title="Board of Control for Cricket in India">Board of Control for Cricket in India</a> (BCCI)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_Premier_League" title="Indian Premier League">Indian Premier League</a> (IPL).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_cricket_team" title="Mumbai cricket team">Mumbai cricket team</a>, the <a href="/wiki/First-class_cricket" title="First-class cricket">first-class</a> team of the city has won 41 <a href="/wiki/Ranji_Trophy" title="Ranji Trophy">Ranji Trophy</a> titles, the most by any team.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup> The city based <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Indians" title="Mumbai Indians">Mumbai Indians</a> compete in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Premier_League" title="Indian Premier League">Indian Premier League</a>. Mumbai has two international cricket grounds, the <a href="/wiki/Wankhede_Stadium" title="Wankhede Stadium">Wankhede Stadium</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Brabourne_Stadium" title="Brabourne Stadium">Brabourne Stadium</a>. The first cricket test match in India was played in Mumbai at the <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Gymkhana" title="Bombay Gymkhana">Bombay Gymkhana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup> The biggest cricketing event to be staged in the city so far is the <a href="/wiki/2011_Cricket_World_Cup_Final" title="2011 Cricket World Cup Final">final</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2011_ICC_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2011 ICC Cricket World Cup">2011 ICC Cricket World Cup</a> which was played at the <a href="/wiki/Wankhede_Stadium" title="Wankhede Stadium">Wankhede Stadium</a>. Mumbai and <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a> are the only two cities to have hosted both a World Cup final and the <a href="/wiki/2006_ICC_Champions_Trophy_Final" title="2006 ICC Champions Trophy Final">final</a> of an <a href="/wiki/ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="ICC Champions Trophy">ICC Champions Trophy</a> which was played at the <a href="/wiki/Brabourne_Stadium" title="Brabourne Stadium">Brabourne Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/2006_ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="2006 ICC Champions Trophy">2006</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSMH_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-TSMH-432">[432]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> is another popular sport in the city, with the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> and the English <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">Premier League</a> being followed widely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Super_League" title="Indian Super League">Indian Super League</a>, the city is represented by <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_City_FC" title="Mumbai City FC">Mumbai City FC</a>. While the city based <a href="/wiki/Kenkre_FC" title="Kenkre FC">Kenkre FC</a> competes in the <a href="/wiki/I-League" title="I-League">I-League</a> (matches in the city are played at the <a href="/wiki/Cooperage_Ground" title="Cooperage Ground">Cooperage Ground</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup> When the <a href="/wiki/Elite_Football_League_of_India" title="Elite Football League of India">Elite Football League of India</a> was introduced in August 2011, Mumbai was noted as one of eight cities to be awarded a team for the inaugural season.
</p><p>Mumbai's first professional <a href="/wiki/American_football" title="American football">American football</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franchise_(sports)" title="Franchise (sports)">franchise</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[435]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Gladiators" title="Mumbai Gladiators">Mumbai Gladiators</a>, played its first season, in <a href="/wiki/Pune" title="Pune">Pune</a>, in late 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey" title="Field hockey">Hockey</a>, Mumbai is home to the <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Marines" title="Mumbai Marines">Mumbai Marines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Magicians" title="Mumbai Magicians">Mumbai Magicians</a> in the <a href="/wiki/World_Series_Hockey" title="World Series Hockey">World Series Hockey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hockey_India_League" title="Hockey India League">Hockey India League</a> respectively. Matches in the city are played at the <a href="/wiki/Mahindra_Hockey_Stadium" title="Mahindra Hockey Stadium">Mahindra Hockey Stadium</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marines_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-marines-437">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-magicians_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-magicians-438">[438]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Indian Badminton League (IBL), now known as the <a href="/wiki/Premier_Badminton_League" title="Premier Badminton League">Premier Badminton League</a> is also visiting Mumbai since its inaugural edition in 2013 when the final was held in Mumbai's <a href="/wiki/National_Sports_Club_of_India" title="National Sports Club of India">National Sports Club of India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> In the second season, the final of the <a href="/wiki/2016_Premier_Badminton_League" title="2016 Premier Badminton League">2016 Premier Badminton League</a> was held between home-squad <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Rockets" title="Mumbai Rockets">Mumbai Rockets</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Dashers" title="Delhi Dashers">Delhi Dashers</a> (formerly Delhi Acers), the visitors eventually claiming the title. The opening ceremony was also held in Mumbai while the finals in <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[440]</a></sup>
In the <a href="/wiki/2017_Premier_Badminton_League" title="2017 Premier Badminton League">2017 Premier Badminton League</a> (also known as Vodafone PBL 2017 for sponsorship reasons) the <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Rockets" title="Mumbai Rockets">Mumbai Rockets</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[441]</a></sup> beat the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyderabad_Hunters_(Badminton_team)" title="Hyderabad Hunters (Badminton team)">Hyderabad Hunters</a> 3–1 to proceed to the final. In the final they lost 3–4 to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chennai_Smashers" title="Chennai Smashers">Chennai Smashers</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/U_Mumba" title="U Mumba">U Mumba</a> is the team representing Mumbai in the country's professional <a href="/wiki/Kabaddi" title="Kabaddi">Kabaddi</a> league, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pro_Kabaddi" title="Pro Kabaddi">Pro Kabaddi</a>. The Mumbai Leg of <a href="/wiki/Pro_Kabaddi_League" title="Pro Kabaddi League">Pro Kabaddi</a> is held at the NSCI, Worli.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">Rugby</a> is another growing sport in Mumbai with league matches being held at the <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Gymkhana" title="Bombay Gymkhana">Bombay Gymkhana</a> from June to November.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rugbyhost_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-rugbyhost-442">[442]</a></sup>
</p><p>Every February, Mumbai holds <a href="/wiki/Derby_(horse_race)" title="Derby (horse race)">derby</a> races at the <a href="/wiki/Mahalaxmi_Racecourse" title="Mahalaxmi Racecourse">Mahalaxmi Racecourse</a>. <a href="/wiki/United_Breweries_Group" title="United Breweries Group">Mcdowell's</a> Derby is also held in February at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Western_India_Turf_Club" title="Royal Western India Turf Club">Turf Club</a> in Mumbai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup> In March 2004, the Mumbai Grand Prix was part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F1_Powerboat_Racing" title="F1 Powerboat Racing">F1 powerboat world championship</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Force_India" title="Force India">Force India</a> F1 team car was unveiled in the city, in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[445]</a></sup> In 2004, the annual <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Marathon" title="Mumbai Marathon">Mumbai Marathon</a> was established as a part of "<a href="/wiki/The_Greatest_Race_on_Earth" title="The Greatest Race on Earth">The Greatest Race on Earth</a>". Mumbai had also played host to the <a href="/wiki/Kingfisher_Airlines_Tennis_Open" title="Kingfisher Airlines Tennis Open">Kingfisher Airlines Tennis Open</a>, an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Series_Tournaments" title="International Series Tournaments">International Series</a> tournament of the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals" title="Association of Tennis Professionals">ATP World Tour</a>, in 2006 and 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[446]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mumbai will host the <a href="/wiki/140th_IOC_Session" title="140th IOC Session">140th IOC Session</a> in 2023. 
</p><p><b>Regional and Professional Sports Teams from Mumbai</b>

<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.freepressjournal.in/amp/mumbai/mumbai-iqbal-chahal-appointed-as-bmc-administrator-as-elections-delayed" rel="nofollow">"Iqbal Chahal appointed as BMC administrator as elections delayed"</a>. <i>The Free Press Journal</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-projectsecoa1-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-projectsecoa1_6-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-projectsecoa1_6-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130513105912/http://www.projectsecoa.eu/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=117&amp;Itemid=73" rel="nofollow">"Mumbai metropolitan area"</a> (in Italian). Projectsecoa.eu. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.projectsecoa.eu/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=117&amp;Itemid=73" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 13 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 March</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Mumbai+metropolitan+area&amp;rft.pub=Projectsecoa.eu&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.projectsecoa.eu%2Findex.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content%26view%3Darticle%26id%3D117%26Itemid%3D73&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMumbai"></span></span>
</li>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-munshi-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-munshi_26-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-munshi_26-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMunshi1954">Munshi, Kanaiyalal M. (1954). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/stream/in.ernet.dli.2015.97812/2015.97812.Gujarat-And-Its-Literature-1852#page/n31/mode/2up/search/Kolis" rel="nofollow"><i>Gujarāt and its literature, from early times to 1852</i></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Vidya_Bhavan_Educational_Trust" title="Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan Educational Trust">Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan</a>. p. xix. <q>The next immigrants into the islands of Bombay were the Kolis, who on all authorities continued to be their original inhabitants till Aungier founded the city of Bombay. Kathiawad and Central Gujarāt was the home of the Kolis in pre-historic times.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Gujar%C4%81t+and+its+literature%2C+from+early+times+to+1852&amp;rft.pages=xix&amp;rft.pub=Bharatiya+Vidya+Bhavan&amp;rft.date=1954&amp;rft.aulast=Munshi&amp;rft.aufirst=Kanaiyalal+M.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fstream%2Fin.ernet.dli.2015.97812%2F2015.97812.Gujarat-And-Its-Literature-1852%23page%2Fn31%2Fmode%2F2up%2Fsearch%2FKolis&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMumbai"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-rnmehta-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-rnmehta_27-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-rnmehta_27-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-rnmehta_27-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFMehta1983">Mehta, R. N. (1983). "Bombay – An analysis of the toponym". <i>Journal of the Oriental Institute</i>: 138–140. <q>The kolis who succeeded the stone-age men on the island brought with them from Gujarat their patron goddess Mummai whom their descendants still worship in Kathiawar. The name of Bombay is derived from this koli goddess.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Oriental+Institute&amp;rft.atitle=Bombay+%E2%80%93+An+analysis+of+the+toponym&amp;rft.pages=138-140&amp;rft.date=1983&amp;rft.aulast=Mehta&amp;rft.aufirst=R.+N.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMumbai"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-mmrda_muip_gdp-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-mmrda_muip_gdp_34-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-mmrda_muip_gdp_34-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-mmrda_muip_gdp_34-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090226031015/http://www.mmrdamumbai.org/projects_muip.htm" rel="nofollow">"Mumbai Urban Infrastructure Project"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Metropolitan_Region_Development_Authority" title="Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority">Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority</a>. <li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100814232747/http://business.rediff.com/slide-show/2010/aug/11/slide-show-1-worst-oil-spills-in-the-world.htm" rel="nofollow">"10 worst oil spills that cost trillions in losses : Rediff.com Business"</a>. <i>Rediff.com</i>. <li id="cite_note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/edu/eesj/gradpubs/GeneralMags/Patel_Archaeology_SlumandSacredCave_0607.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The Slum and the Sacred Cave"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <li id="cite_note-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-80">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20081021063323/http://asi.nic.in/asi_monu_whs_elephanta.asp" rel="nofollow">"World Heritage Sites – Elephanta Caves"</a>. <li id="cite_note-107"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-107">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKincaidPārasanīsa1922">Kincaid, Charles Augustus; Pārasanīsa, Dattātraya Baḷavanta (1922). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6fVBAQAAMAAJ&amp;q=Gohagad+koli" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of the Maratha People</i></a>. H. Milford, Oxford University Press.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+the+Maratha+People&amp;rft.pub=H.+Milford%2C+Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1922&amp;rft.aulast=Kincaid&amp;rft.aufirst=Charles+Augustus&amp;rft.au=P%C4%81rasan%C4%ABsa%2C+Datt%C4%81traya+Ba%E1%B8%B7avanta&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D6fVBAQAAMAAJ%26q%3DGohagad%2Bkoli&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMumbai"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-y72-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-y72_108-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-y72_108-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#yakg">Yimene 2004</a>, p. 94</span>

<li id="cite_note-160"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-160">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFSrinivasuPardeshi">Srinivasu, T.; Pardeshi, Satish. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090717023146/http://iscmumbai.maharashtra.gov.in/floristic%20survey.html" rel="nofollow">"Floristic Survey of Institute of Science, Mumbai, Maharashtra State"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Maharashtra" title="Government of Maharashtra">Government of Maharashtra</a>. <li id="cite_note-autaxi-252"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-autaxi_252-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-autaxi_252-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFGhose2005">Ghose, Anindita (24 August 2005). <a class="external text" href="http://www.dnaindia.com/speakup/report_what-s-mumbai-without-the-black-beetles_422" rel="nofollow">"What's Mumbai without the black beetles?"</a>. <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/DNA_(newspaper)" title="DNA (newspaper)">Daily News and Analysis</a> (DNA)</i>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110728070112/http://www.dnaindia.com/speakup/report_what-s-mumbai-without-the-black-beetles_422" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 28 July 2011<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 August</span> 2009</span>. <q>In Mumbai autos run only in the suburbs up to Mahim creek. This is probably the perfect arrangement because it is not economically viable for autos and taxis to solicit the same passengers. So autos monopolise the suburbs while taxis rule South Mumbai.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+News+and+Analysis+%28DNA%29&amp;rft.atitle=What%27s+Mumbai+without+the+black+beetles%3F&amp;rft.date=2005-08-24&amp;rft.aulast=Ghose&amp;rft.aufirst=Anindita&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dnaindia.com%2Fspeakup%2Freport_what-s-mumbai-without-the-black-beetles_422&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMumbai"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-census2011-344"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-census2011_344-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-census2011_344-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/c-01.html" rel="nofollow">"C-1 Population By Religious Community"</a>. <li><a href="/wiki/Kolkata" title="Kolkata">Kolkata</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Mumbai</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nainital" title="Nainital">Nainital</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/New_Delhi" title="New Delhi">New Delhi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Patna" title="Patna">Patna</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ranchi" title="Ranchi">Ranchi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shillong" title="Shillong">Shillong</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shimla" title="Shimla">Shimla</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Srinagar" title="Srinagar">Srinagar</a> (<i>summer</i>)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
